sen.j: 古空穂（ふるうつぼ）または空穂（うつぼ）とは、鳥山石燕の妖怪画集『百器徒然袋』にある日本の妖怪。
sen.e: Furuutsubo or Utsubo is a Japanese specter portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's book of specter paintings, "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (One hundred bags in idlenss).

A Furu-utsubo or Utsubo is a Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book named "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (The Bag of One Hundred Random Demons; the term 'hyakki' in its title is a pun on the usual hyakki, replacing the character for demon which is written as "鬼" in Japanese with a character for vessel written as "器," and sure enough, most of the yokais shown in this book are tsukumogami [a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive]).

Furu-utsubo or Utsubo is a Japanese yokai (ghosts, spirits and monsters) portrayed in Sekien TORIYAMA's yokai art collection book named "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro" (The Bag of One Hundred Random Demons; the term 'hyakki' in its title is a pun on the usual hyakki, replacing the character for demon which is written as "鬼" in Japanese with a character for vessel written as "器," and sure enough, most of the yokais shown in this book are tsukumogami [a type of Japanese spirits that originate in items or artifacts that have reached their 100th birthday and become alive]).

sen.j: 空穂とは矢を入れて背負う道具のことである。
sen.e: Utsubo refers an arrow quiver, carried on the back.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: A utsubo refers to an arrow quiver to be carried on the back.
A utsubo refers to an arrow quiver to be carried on the back.

sen.j: 『百器徒然袋』の解説文によれば、この「古空穂」は元は那須野ヶ原で野干を射たという三浦義明の空穂だったとある。
sen.e: According to the expository writing of "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro", the "Furuutsubo" (old quiver) belonged to Yoshiaki MIURA who shot foxes in the field of Nasuno district.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: According to the expository writing of "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro," the "Furu-utsubo" (an old quiver) used to belong to Yoshiaki MIURA who shot yakan (Buddhist legendary animals, which initially referred to jackals in India and later foxes in Japan) in Nasunogahara fields.
sen.cmt: 辞書や現地サイトによると地名は「那須野ヶ原」となっていますので、修正のうえ再訳出しました。http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=那須野&dtype=0&stype=1&dname=0na&ref=1&index=15929813755000 http://www.park-tochigi.com/nasunogahara/
sen.e: According to the expository writing of "Hyakki Tsurezure Bukuro," the 'Furu-utsubo' (an old quiver) used to belong to Yoshiaki MIURA who shot yakan (Buddhist legendary animals, which initially referred to jackals in India and later foxes in Japan) in Nasunogahara fields.

sen.j: その三浦介の空穂が付喪神と化し、獣のように動き回るようになったものが、妖怪の古空穂とされる。
sen.e: It is said that Furuutsubo, the specter is one of Tsukumo-gami (gods to a variety of things) that was mutated from the Miura no suke's quiver and started to move around like a beast.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: It is said that the yokai 'Furu-utubo' is one of the tsukumogami which was transmuted from the Miura no suke's quiver and started to move around like a beast.
It is said that the yokai 'Furu-utubo' is one of the tsukumogami which was transmuted from the Miura no suke's quiver and started to move around like a beast.

sen.j: 三浦介は上総（介）広常とともに那須野ヶ原で九尾の狐を仕留めたといわれる。
sen.e: Together with Hirotsune KAZUSA, Miura no suke allegedly brought down a nine-tailed fox in the field of the Nasuno district.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Together with Kazusa (no suke) (deputy governor of Kazusa Province) Hirotsune, Miura no suke allegedly shot down a nine-tailed fox in Nasunogahara.
sen.cmt: 「上総」は上総介＝上総の国の国司の次官という官職名であるため、名字としての大文字化はしません。原文に（介）を補足しました。また、地名は辞書や現地サイトによると「那須野ヶ原」となっていますので、修正のうえ再訳出しました。
sen.e: Together with Kazusa (no suke) (deputy governor of Kazusa Province) Hirotsune, Miura no suke allegedly shot down a nine-tailed fox in Nasunogahara.

sen.j: 歳月を経たことでかつての栄光を忘れられたため、空穂が妖怪と化したとする説がある。
sen.e: Some say that his quiver turned into the specter because his past glory was forgotten as the time passes.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Some say that his quiver turned into yokai because his past glory had been forgotten as time passed.
sen.cmt: 原文「忘れられため」を修正しました。
sen.e: Some say that his quiver turned into yokai because his past glory had been forgotten as time passed.

sen.j: また、矢入れの空穂は多くは漆塗りの竹が用いられるが、中には毛皮や羽毛の貼られたものもある。
sen.e: Moreover, the arrow quivers are usually made of lacquered bamboo, but some of them have fur or feathers applyed inside.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Generally, arrow quivers were made of lacquered bamboo, but some of them had fur or feathers applied inside.
Generally, arrow quivers were made of lacquered bamboo, but some of them had fur or feathers applied inside.

sen.j: そのような動物製のものの方がこのような付喪神になりやすいとする説もある。
sen.e: Some say that such animal products tend to become the Tsukumo-gami.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: One theory has it that items including animal body parts are more prone to transmuting into tsukumogami.
One theory has it that items including animal body parts are more prone to transmuting into tsukumogami.
